title: 115_s864
content: The "Balkan Economic Partnership Act" is the short title of this legislation, with the purpose and findings outlined in the following section. The "Balkan Economic Partnership Act" aims to support economic opportunity and political progress in Bosnia and Herzegovina through an enterprise fund for small and medium-sized enterprises. Congress recognizes the importance of preventing economic challenges from overshadowing stability and reconciliation efforts since the Bosnian War. Unemployment rates exceeding 40% have led to widespread frustration and protests in the country. Economic growth among small and medium-sized enterprises is crucial for progress in Bosnia and Herzegovina. Bank lending and private sector credit-to-GDP ratio in Bosnia and Herzegovina have stagnated since 2008, hindering growth for small and medium-sized enterprises. International financial institutions and foreign-owned investment funds have focused on larger companies and infrastructure projects, neglecting SMEs. Bosnia and Herzegovina's demographic, income, and geographic characteristics are conducive for SME growth, with a market of almost 4 million people and a growing per capita income. The country imports nearly $10 billion worth of goods annually, presenting opportunities for domestic SME production. Congressional acts like the SEED Act of 1989 have aimed to support the private sector in Central and Eastern Europe post-Berlin Wall. The FREEDOM Support Act authorized $1.2 billion for USAID to establish 10 Enterprise Funds, which channeled $10 billion into 500 enterprises, leveraged $6.9 billion in private investment, created/sustained 300,000 jobs, and provided development capital in 19 countries. Establishing an enterprise fund for Bosnia and Herzegovina would help sustain and expand economic reform efforts, improve financial institutions, and empower entrepreneurs to create employment opportunities. This initiative has proven beneficial in other European countries like Poland, Hungary, and Albania, with a recoup rate of 177 percent of the original USAID funding. Establishing an enterprise fund for Herzegovina would improve financial institutions, provide investment opportunities for SMEs, and attract both domestic and international investors. The Bosnia and Herzegovina-American Enterprise Fund is established to improve financial institutions, provide investment opportunities for SMEs, and attract domestic and international investors. The Bosnia and Herzegovina-American Enterprise Fund aims to promote shared prosperity through private sector development in Bosnia and Herzegovina, including providing loans, investments, grants, and technical assistance to small and medium-sized enterprises. It also focuses on promoting sound corporate governance and Western business practices. The Bosnia and Herzegovina-American Enterprise Fund promotes private sector development by supporting small and medium-sized enterprises, improving the business environment, and demonstrating profitable private sector investment. The Bosnia and Herzegovina-American Enterprise Fund supports private sector development by aiding small and medium-sized enterprises and enhancing the business environment. The President can designate a private, nonprofit organization called the Bosnia and Herzegovina-American Enterprise Fund to receive funds for specified purposes. The Fund is governed by a Board of Directors, consisting of 7 US citizens appointed by the President in consultation with the Administrator of the US Agency for International Development. Up to 3 additional members from Bosnia and Herzegovina can be elected unanimously by the Board. Members must have business experience. The Board of Directors of the Bosnia and Herzegovina-American Enterprise Fund consists of 7 US citizens appointed by the President, with 4 members having successful business careers in international investment activities and 3 members with development experience in Bosnia and Herzegovina. The President appoints US government liaisons to the Board of Directors of the Bosnia and Herzegovina-American Enterprise Fund. $30,000,000 is authorized for the Department of State in fiscal year 2018 for the Fund's purposes and administrative expenses. Compliance requirements are also specified. The Bosnia and Herzegovina-American Enterprise Fund must comply with specific requirements to receive grants, including ending its reinvestment cycle by December 31, 2033 unless an extension is approved by the Secretary of State. The grant agreement between the United States Agency for International Development and the Bosnia and Herzegovina-American Enterprise Fund must comply with procedures to prevent money laundering and terrorist financing. Grant funds cannot be provided to entities involved in such activities. The Bosnia and Herzegovina-American Enterprise Fund's assets will be returned to the US Treasury to reduce the national debt upon dissolution. If the Fund's assets exceed the total amount appropriated, a legacy foundation may be authorized. The Secretary of State, in consultation with the Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development, can direct excess funds to a foundation for activities aligned with the Fund's purposes. The President must notify congressional committees 15 days before designating an organization to operate as the Bosnia and Herzegovina-American Enterprise Fund. The information required for the Bosnia and Herzegovina-American Enterprise Fund includes the organization's identity, the Chairman of the Board of Directors, and the grant amount for the fund. SEC. 5. REPORTS. The Fund must report administrative expenses annually and provide a GAO report on investments, management structures, and compliance. The Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development must commission independent reports on the performance of the Bosnia and Herzegovina-American Enterprise Fund, to be provided to appropriate congressional committees. The term "appropriate congressional committees" refers to specific committees in the Senate and House of Representatives, including the Committee on Foreign Relations and the Committee on Appropriations in the Senate, and the Committee on Foreign Affairs and the Committee on Appropriations in the House of Representatives. SEC. 6. OPERATION PROVISIONS. Applicable Provisions from the SEED Act of 1989 apply to the Bosnia and Herzegovina-American Enterprise Fund. Returns on investments can be reinvested without further appropriation by Congress. SEC. 7. BEST PRACTICES AND PROCEDURES. SEC. 7. BEST PRACTICES AND PROCEDURES. The Board of Directors of the Bosnia and Herzegovina-American Enterprise Fund should adopt best practices and procedures used by Enterprise Funds funded under the SEED Act of 1989.
